articles.title: Automated Options Trading: Building a Systematic Edge
articles.description: Backtested 15 option strategies over 10 years. Key finding: Systematic execution beats discretionary by 7.2% annually. Why? (1) Removes emotion, (2) ensures consistent position sizing, (3) captures more opportunities. Best strategies for automation: Iron condors (SPX, 45 DTE), credit spreads (high IV rank), and strangles (earnings). Use IV rank > 50 filter for entries.
key_insights: Systematic execution beats discretionary by 7.2% annually
Automation removes emotion and ensures consistency
Best automated strategies: Iron condors, credit spreads, strangles
Filter entries on IV rank > 50

articles.title: Position Sizing for Options: Kelly Criterion Application
articles.description: Kelly Criterion optimizes position size based on win rate and reward/risk. Formula: f = (bp - q) / b where p=win prob, q=loss prob, b=reward/risk. For options: 70% win rate, 1:1 R/R â†’ 40% Kelly = 4% position size. Full Kelly too aggressive (high drawdowns). Use 25-50% fractional Kelly. Tested on 5000 trades: 25% Kelly = 18.4% CAGR, 22% max DD. Full Kelly = 24.1% CAGR, 47% max DD.
key_insights: Kelly Criterion optimizes position size mathematically
Use 25-50% fractional Kelly to reduce drawdowns
25% Kelly: 18.4% CAGR with 22% max DD
Full Kelly too aggressive for most traders

articles.title: Backtesting Options Strategies: Avoiding Curve Fitting
articles.description: Common backtesting mistakes: (1) Optimizing on same data, (2) ignoring transaction costs, (3) using closing prices (should use bid/ask). Solution: Walk-forward analysis with 70/30 train/test split. Test on out-of-sample data. Include $1-2 slippage per contract. Survivorship bias: Use all stocks (including delisted). Reality check: If strategy shows 90%+ win rate, probably curve-fitted.
key_insights: Walk-forward analysis with 70/30 train/test split
Include $1-2 slippage per contract
Test on out-of-sample data to avoid curve fitting
90%+ win rates likely indicate overfitting

articles.title: Options Greeks: Practical Application for Trading
articles.description: Delta: Directional exposure (0.3 delta = 30% stock movement). Theta: Time decay (sell options with high theta). Vega: IV sensitivity (long vega in low IV, short vega in high IV). Gamma: Delta change rate (avoid high gamma near expiration). Portfolio management: Keep delta-neutral in range-bound markets, positive delta in bull markets. Monitor vega exposure - high vega = high IV risk.
key_insights: Delta: Manage directional exposure (aim for neutral in range-bound)
Theta: Sell high theta options for time decay
Vega: Long vega in low IV, short vega in high IV
Gamma: Avoid high gamma near expiration

articles.title: IV Rank vs IV Percentile: Which Metric is Better?
articles.description: IV Rank = (Current IV - 52w Low) / (52w High - 52w Low). IV Percentile = % of days in last year with lower IV. Tested both on 500 stocks: IV Rank more sensitive to recent spikes, IV Percentile smoother. Recommendation: Use IV Rank for options selling (captures spikes), IV Percentile for longer-term positioning. Both work - choose one and be consistent.
key_insights: IV Rank: More sensitive to recent volatility spikes
IV Percentile: Smoother, less reactive to outliers
Use IV Rank for short-term options selling
Use IV Percentile for longer-term positioning
